newsitem.title: CONGO: Angry troops block French envoy in Brazzaville.
newsitem.headline: Angry troops block French envoy in Brazzaville.

text.p: Angry soldiers loyal to Congo Republic President Pascal Lissouba prevented France's ambassador leaving Brazzaville's embattled city centre on Saturday, effectively trapping him in his embassy.

The soldiers, who were manning a roadblock, refused to let Ambassador Raymond Cesaire, other French diplomats and journalists leave the area in a convoy for the comparative safety of the ambassador's residence even though they had an official Congolese escort with them.
The soldiers appeared to have no commander and an anti-French attitude.
Earlier, commanders in the warring factions in the capital agreed verbally to a new week-long ceasefire.

Fighting eased on Saturday but as during previous truces in a three-week showdown between Lissouba and his predecessor, former Marxist military ruler Denis Sassou Nguesso, some shooting continued as the rival forces jockeyed for position.

Civilians, fearing for their lives after battles in which the indiscriminate use of rockets and mortars has made anyone and everyone a target, jostled to take trucks and buses out of the southern suburbs -- relatively unscathed to date.
Military chiefs agreed late on Friday to order a truce for a week, but neutral mediators under mayor Bernard Kolelas, having seen previous accords fall apart, were cautious.

"This was agreed orally but not in writing because we prefer that the population should be the ones who decide if the ceasefire really takes hold," an aide to Kolelas, whose own fighters have kept out of the conflict to date, told Reuters.
"The ceasefires here are like fish -- good when fresh, then they go off," one French official in the city commented.
Cesaire tried to take advantage of Saturday's lull to make a dash to his residence, a former home of General Charles de Gaulle, in the calmer southern Bacongo suburb.
It was his first trip out in several days.
Former colonial power France protested to Lissouba last week after his men assaulted Cesaire, beat up his bodyguard and fired shots at his escort after a visit to the presidency.

Tens of thousands of people fled the city on Thursday and Friday after a battle to control the international airport ignited the heaviest artillery exchanges so far. Both sides claimed victory but independent confirmation was not possible.
More of the city's one million residents jostled to get a place on trucks or buses that were leaving on Saturday, heading into the countryside from the southern suburbs.
These suburbs, held by Kolelas militia, had provided refuge to people fleeing the front line that bisects the city centre. This week dozens of shells, presumably strays, landed there.

Medical workers estimate that 1,000 to 3,000 people, mostly civilians caught in crossfire, have died since the clashes began on June 5 when Lissouba moved to disarm Sassou's "Cobra" militia in the run-up to a July 27 presidential election.
The president has accused Sassou Nguesso of trying to stage a coup, Sassou Nguesso says Lissouba provoked trouble to cling on to power beyond the now suspended presidential election.

Lissouba has pleaded for immediate military help from France via his ambassador in Paris. "If France does not act as rapidly as possible, Congo's democratic regime will live or perish in bloodshed," wrote Pierre-Michel Nguimbi.
Paris pulled out some 1,250 soldiers over a week ago after evacuating almost 6,000 foreign nationals, and has declined to supply troops for a proposed U.N. peacekeeping force.
